questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the diagnosis of an infant with PHPV?

options.label: A
options.text: PHPV is the result of failure of regression of fetal vasculature and can present as leukocoria.

options.label: B
options.text: PHPV is frequently associated with Down syndrome.

options.label: C
options.text: Anterior PHPV generally has a poor prognosis due to the high likelihood of amblyopia.

options.label: D
options.text: Calcification is a common finding in PHPV and should be expected in this case.

questions.correct_answer: A. PHPV is the result of failure of regression of fetal vasculature and can present as leukocoria.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PHPV is the result of failure of regression of fetal vasculature and can present as leukocoria.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is a non-hereditary, congenital anomaly due to the failure of the fetal hyaloid artery to regress, often presenting unilaterally with leukocoria, and is associated with a good prognosis when anterior without calcification.
  • ➤ Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV) is a non-hereditary, congenital anomaly due to the failure of the fetal hyaloid artery to regress, often presenting unilaterally with leukocoria, and is associated with a good prognosis when anterior without calcification.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about blackouts except:

options.label: A
options.text: The person appears confused to the onlookers

options.label: B
options.text: Remote memory is relatively intact during the blackout

options.label: C
options.text: It is a discrete episode of anterograde amnesia

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with alcohol intoxication

questions.correct_answer: A. The person appears confused to the onlookers
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A blackout, often induced by alcohol intoxication, is characterized by an episode of anterograde amnesia without the overt appearance of confusion or disorientation. Individuals may appear to be functioning normally to onlooker’s despite being unable to form new memories.
  • ➤ A blackout, often induced by alcohol intoxication, is characterized by an episode of anterograde amnesia without the overt appearance of confusion or disorientation.
  • ➤ Individuals may appear to be functioning normally to onlooker’s despite being unable to form new memories.

questions.text: In a pediatric patient at high risk for severe respiratory illness, Palivizumab can be administered to prevent complications associated with which viral infection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Respiratory syncytial virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Palivizumab is a monoclonal antibody approved for the prevention of serious lower respiratory tract disease caused by RSV in children at high risk for RSV disease.
  • ➤ Palivizumab is a monoclonal antibody approved for the prevention of serious lower respiratory tract disease caused by RSV in children at high risk for RSV disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old university student had a fight with the neighbouring boy. On the next day while out, he started feeling that two men in police uniform were observing his movements. When he reached home in the evening he was frightened and told his family members that police were after him and would arrest him. Despite reassurances by family members, he remained afraid that he is about to be arrested. The history is suggestive of which psychiatric sign/symptom:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The history is suggestive of a delusion of persecution, which is a belief that one is going to be harmed by others – in this case, the police. It's a common symptom in psychiatric conditions such as psychosis where the individual's belief system is out of touch with reality.
  • ➤ The history is suggestive of a delusion of persecution, which is a belief that one is going to be harmed by others – in this case, the police.
  • ➤ It's a common symptom in psychiatric conditions such as psychosis where the individual's belief system is out of touch with reality.

questions.text: A male patient with benign hypertrophy of the prostate was hospitalized for three weeks. During his stay, he developed signs suggestive of a catheter-associated urinary tract infection (UTI). The tip of his urinary catheter was cultured on blood agar and, after 24 hours, the agar showed the distinctive pattern as in the image provided. Which organism is most likely the causative agent of the UTI in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Blood agar with swarming motility is suggestive of Proteus.
  • ➤ Blood agar with swarming motility is suggestive of Proteus.

questions.text: A student after a heavy lunch from the hostel got ready for his afternoon class. After a while he yawned widely. To his surprise sadly he could not close his mouth. The jaw was stuck. Which of the following statement is not true in the above scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: This is a case of anterior dislocation of temporomandibular joint

options.label: B
options.text: Temporomandibular joint is a bicondylar type of synovial joint

options.label: C
options.text: Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible

options.label: D
options.text: Sphenomandibular ligament is situated medial to temporomandibular joint

questions.correct_answer: C. Contraction of medial pterygoid depresses the mandible
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The medial pterygoid muscle functions to elevate the mandible, not depress it. In the context of a TMJ dislocation, which often occurs with an anterior dislocation after activities such as yawning, the inability to close the mouth is a key clinical sign. Understanding the anatomy and function of the muscles of mastication and the ligaments of the TMJ is important for diagnosing and managing TMJ disorders.
  • ➤ The medial pterygoid muscle functions to elevate the mandible, not depress it. In the context of a TMJ dislocation, which often occurs with an anterior dislocation after activities such as yawning, the inability to close the mouth is a key clinical sign.
  • ➤ Understanding the anatomy and function of the muscles of mastication and the ligaments of the TMJ is important for diagnosing and managing TMJ disorders.

questions.text: Identify the correct statements: Tranexamic acid reduces risk of mortality only in patients of penetrating trauma with no role in blunt trauma cases All patients after trauma with signs of shock should receive tranexamic acid within 3 hours of injury Crystalloids are preferred over blood and blood products for resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients of trauma The first step in primary survey in field trauma patient is control of any exsanguinating hemorrhage
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2,4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Based on the given statements, let's identify the correct ones regarding the management of trauma patients:
  • • 1. Tranexamic acid reduces risk of mortality only in patients of penetrating trauma with no role in blunt trauma cases This statement is incorrect. Tranexamic acid has been shown to reduce the risk of mortality from bleeding in both penetrating and blunt trauma cases, as evidenced by the CRASH-2 trial.
  • • 1. Tranexamic acid reduces risk of mortality only in patients of penetrating trauma with no role in blunt trauma cases
  • • 2. All patients with signs of shock should receive tranexamic acid within 3 hours of injury This statement is correct. The CRASH-2 trial also indicated that tranexamic acid is beneficial when administered within 3 hours of injury to patients with signs of significant hemorrhage or shock.
  • • 2. All patients with signs of shock should receive tranexamic acid within 3 hours of injury
  • • 3. Crystalloids are preferred over blood and blood products for resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients of trauma This statement is incorrect. In severely hypovolemic trauma patients, blood and blood products are preferred to restore circulating volume and oxygen-carrying capacity. Crystalloids can be used temporarily while awaiting blood products but are not the resuscitation fluid of choice in severe hemorrhage.
  • • 3. Crystalloids are preferred over blood and blood products for resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients of trauma
  • • 4. The first step in primary survey in field trauma patient is control of any exsanguinating haemorrhage This statement is correct. In trauma care, particularly in the pre-hospital setting, the first step in the primary survey is to control any life-threatening external hemorrhage before proceeding with airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) assessment and management.
  • • 4. The first step in primary survey in field trauma patient is control of any exsanguinating haemorrhage
  • • The correct options, therefore, are 2 and 4 .
  • • 2 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key points in trauma management include administering tranexamic acid within 3 hours to patients with signs of significant hemorrhage, using blood and blood products for the resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients, and controlling life-threatening hemorrhage as a first step in the primary survey of trauma patients.
  • ➤ The key points in trauma management include administering tranexamic acid within 3 hours to patients with signs of significant hemorrhage, using blood and blood products for the resuscitation of severely hypovolemic patients, and controlling life-threatening hemorrhage as a first step in the primary survey of trauma patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with musculoskeletal pain localized to her right shoulder. She reports the pain intensifies during her daily activities such as lifting objects but eases when at rest without movement. Radiographs of the shoulder show no joint space narrowing or bony abnormalities. Which of the following features most strongly suggests a non-articular origin for her shoulder pain?

options.label: A
options.text: Pain or decreased range of motion on active and passive movement both

options.label: D
options.text: Pain on active movement but not on passive movement

questions.correct_answer: D. Pain on active movement but not on passive movement
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ability to differentiate non-articular from articular pain is essential in musculoskeletal assessment. Non-articular pain typically occurs with active but not passive movement, suggesting involvement of periarticular tissues like muscles or tendons rather than the joint itself.
  • ➤ The ability to differentiate non-articular from articular pain is essential in musculoskeletal assessment.
  • ➤ Non-articular pain typically occurs with active but not passive movement, suggesting involvement of periarticular tissues like muscles or tendons rather than the joint itself.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male is brought by his wife. He thinks that he had committed sins throughout his life. He is very much depressed and has considered committing suicide but has not taken any such steps. He is also taking sessions with a spiritual guru. He does not get convinced when his wife tells him that he has led a pious life. How will you treat him?

options.label: C
options.text: Guidance and recounseling with guru plus antidepressant

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient exhibiting signs of depression coupled with delusional guilt, the treatment plan should include both an antidepressant to manage the mood disorder and an antipsychotic to address psychotic symptoms.
  • ➤ In a patient exhibiting signs of depression coupled with delusional guilt, the treatment plan should include both an antidepressant to manage the mood disorder and an antipsychotic to address psychotic symptoms.

questions.text: Vaccine associated paralytic poliomyelitis is defined as those cases of acute flaccid paralysis?

options.label: A
options.text: Who have residual weakness 6 months after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, vaccine related poliovirus but no wild virus is isolated.

options.label: B
options.text: Who have residual weakness 60 days after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, vaccine related poliovirus but no wild virus is isolated.

options.label: C
options.text: Who have residual weakness 6 days after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, vaccine related poliovirus but no wild virus is isolated.

options.label: D
options.text: Who have residual weakness 60 days after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, wild polio virus is isolated.

questions.correct_answer: B. Who have residual weakness 60 days after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, vaccine related poliovirus but no wild virus is isolated.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Who have residual weakness 60 days after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, vaccine related poliovirus but no wild virus is isolated

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vaccine associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP) is defined as those cases of AFP which have residual weakness 60 days after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, vaccine-related poliovirus but no wild poliovirus is isolated.
  • ➤ Vaccine associated paralytic poliomyelitis (VAPP) is defined as those cases of AFP which have residual weakness 60 days after the onset of paralysis and from whose stool samples, vaccine-related poliovirus but no wild poliovirus is isolated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a sudden, severe headache, visual disturbances, and difficulty moving the left eye outward. Imaging reveals an aneurysm near the Circle of Willis. Which cranial nerve is most likely to be compressed between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery due to the aneurysm?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oculomotor Nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Occulomotor Nerve : The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is responsible for controlling several eye muscles that move the eye and control the size of the pupil. It also plays a role in raising the eyelid . It is the cranial nerve that runs between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery as it courses through the interpeduncular fossa within the brainstem .
  • ➤ Occulomotor Nerve : The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is responsible for controlling several eye muscles that move the eye and control the size of the pupil. It also plays a role in raising the eyelid . It is the cranial nerve that runs between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery as it courses through the interpeduncular fossa within the brainstem .
  • ➤ Occulomotor Nerve
  • ➤ The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is responsible for controlling several eye muscles that move the eye and control the size of the pupil. It also plays a role in raising the eyelid . It is the cranial nerve that runs between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery as it courses through the interpeduncular fossa within the brainstem .
  • ➤ The oculomotor nerve (CN III) is responsible for controlling several eye muscles that move the eye and control the size of the pupil.
  • ➤ controlling several eye muscles
  • ➤ control the size
  • ➤ It also plays a role in raising the eyelid .
  • ➤ raising the eyelid
  • ➤ It is the cranial nerve that runs between the superior cerebellar artery and posterior cerebral artery as it courses through the interpeduncular fossa within the brainstem .
  • ➤ interpeduncular fossa within the brainstem

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents with a two-day history of fever and altered mental status. On examination, her legs are covered with the rash pictured, her blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg, and neck stiffness is noted. Laboratory analysis of lumbar puncture samples reveals cloudy, turbid cerebrospinal fluid with a white cell count of 4200 cells/µL, protein level of 168, and glucose of 21 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely Gram stain characteristic of the organism responsible for her symptoms?

options.label: B
options.text: Gram-negative diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose

options.label: C
options.text: Gram-positive cocci, catalase negative, bacitracin sensitive

options.label: D
options.text: Gram-positive diplococci (lanceolate), catalase negative, optochin sensitive

questions.correct_answer: B. Gram-negative diplococci, ferments glucose and maltose
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical history of meningitis with a typical purpuric rash is seen in Meningococcal infection. Meningococci are Gram Negative diplococci, ferment glucose and maltose both, in contrast to gonococci which ferment only glucose.
  • ➤ The clinical history of meningitis with a typical purpuric rash is seen in Meningococcal infection. Meningococci are Gram Negative diplococci, ferment glucose and maltose both, in contrast to gonococci which ferment only glucose.

questions.text: Which of the following features are seen by the lesion of the marked structure in the given image?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Contralateral Hemiplegia : This is paralysis on the side of the body opposite to the side of the brain where the lesion is located. Lesions in the motor pathways , especially in the cerebral cortex or internal capsule , can lead to contralateral hemiplegia because motor fibers decussate (cross over) in the medulla .
  • ➤ Contralateral Hemiplegia : This is paralysis on the side of the body opposite to the side of the brain where the lesion is located.
  • ➤ Contralateral Hemiplegia
  • ➤ paralysis
  • ➤ side
  • ➤ body opposite
  • ➤ side
  • ➤ brain
  • ➤ Lesions in the motor pathways , especially in the cerebral cortex or internal capsule , can lead to contralateral hemiplegia because motor fibers decussate (cross over) in the medulla .
  • ➤ motor pathways
  • ➤ cerebral cortex
  • ➤ internal capsule
  • ➤ contralateral hemiplegia
  • ➤ motor fibers
  • ➤ decussate (cross over)
  • ➤ medulla

questions.text: In a patient undergoing treatment for head and neck cancer, the decision on the extent of neck dissection is crucial. A supra omohyoid selective neck dissection involves the removal of which levels of lymph nodes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Levels I, II, III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The supraomohyoid selective neck dissection typically involves removal of lymph nodes at levels I, II, and III and is used primarily for oral cavity cancers where these levels are most commonly affected by metastases.
  • ➤ The supraomohyoid selective neck dissection typically involves removal of lymph nodes at levels I, II, and III and is used primarily for oral cavity cancers where these levels are most commonly affected by metastases.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty bringing his fingers together and separating them. He also mentions that he has trouble bending his fingers at the knuckles while keeping the rest of the finger straight. Physical examination reveals atrophy in the spaces between the bones of the hand. Based on the patient's symptoms and physical exam findings, which group of muscles is most likely impaired?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Interossei

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The interossei muscles are primarily responsible for adducting and abducting the fingers, and their paralysis can lead to difficulty in performing these actions. The lumbricals contribute to flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints and extending the interphalangeal joints, but they are not the primary muscles for finger adduction.
  • ➤ The interossei muscles are primarily responsible for adducting and abducting the fingers, and their paralysis can lead to difficulty in performing these actions. The lumbricals contribute to flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints and extending the interphalangeal joints, but they are not the primary muscles for finger adduction.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a four-day history of sore throat. Examination reveals enlarged tonsils with a yellow-grayish exudate and a pronounced foul odor. He has a high fever and enlarged cervical lymph nodes. Which of the following non-suppurative complications should be of concern in this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Both acute rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis

questions.correct_answer: C. Both acute rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both acute rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient presents with pharyngitis and the mentioned clinical features, it is crucial to consider both acute rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis as potential non-suppurative complications, especially in the context of streptococcal infection.
  • ➤ When a patient presents with pharyngitis and the mentioned clinical features, it is crucial to consider both acute rheumatic fever and acute glomerulonephritis as potential non-suppurative complications, especially in the context of streptococcal infection.

questions.text: In a clinical assessment scenario, a patient presents with symptoms indicative of a respiratory infection, characterized by cough with rusty sputum, lower lobe consolidation, and bronchial breath sounds. The organism responsible for this infection was also found to give a positive Quellung reaction. Based on these clinical and laboratory findings, what is the probable Gram staining appearance of the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ History of lobar consolidation –indicates lobar pneumonia Quellung test positive- indicates pneumococcal pneumonia Pneumococci are Gram positive diplococci, lanceolate shaped
  • ➤ History of lobar consolidation –indicates lobar pneumonia
  • ➤ Quellung test positive- indicates pneumococcal pneumonia
  • ➤ Pneumococci are Gram positive diplococci, lanceolate shaped

questions.text: Which of the following is true about arterial supply to the heart?

options.label: A
options.text: The SA Node is supplied by Left Coronary Artery

options.label: B
options.text: Coronary predominance is based on origin of Anterior Interventricular Branch

options.label: C
options.text: The Interventricular Septum is supplied only by Right Coronary Artery

options.label: D
options.text: The trunk of Left Coronary Artery is very short

questions.correct_answer: D. The trunk of Left Coronary Artery is very short
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The trunk of Left Coronary Artery is very short

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The left coronary artery has a very short trunk before it bifurcates into the left anterior descending and left circumflex arteries. The sinoatrial node is usually supplied by the right coronary artery in a right-dominant circulation, and the interventricular septum receives blood supply from both the left and right coronary arteries.
  • ➤ The left coronary artery has a very short trunk before it bifurcates into the left anterior descending and left circumflex arteries.
  • ➤ The sinoatrial node is usually supplied by the right coronary artery in a right-dominant circulation, and the interventricular septum receives blood supply from both the left and right coronary arteries.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is not primarily associated with a dysfunction in phagocytosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Disorders of phagocytosis
  • ➤ Disorders of phagocytosis
  • ➤ Disorders of phagocytosis
  • ➤ Chronic granulomatous disease Myeloperoxidase deficiency Chediak-Higashi syndrome Leukocyte adhesion deficiency Lazy leukocyte syndrome Job’s syndrome or Hyper-IgE syndrome Tuftsin deficiency Shwachman’s disease
  • ➤ Chronic granulomatous disease
  • ➤ Myeloperoxidase deficiency
  • ➤ Chediak-Higashi syndrome
  • ➤ Leukocyte adhesion deficiency
  • ➤ Lazy leukocyte syndrome
  • ➤ Job’s syndrome or Hyper-IgE syndrome
  • ➤ Tuftsin deficiency
  • ➤ Shwachman’s disease

questions.text: For a child presenting with a groin swelling that exhibits a gurgling sound upon reduction, which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: B
options.text: The hernia lies above and medial to the pubic tubercle.

options.label: C
options.text: There is a patent processus vaginalis.

options.label: D
options.text: This type of hernia requires surgery promptly.

questions.correct_answer: A. The sac contains omentum only.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The sac contains omentum only.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The statement "The sac contains omentum only" is incorrect when describing an indirect inguinal hernia in children, as these hernias may contain bowel, which is consistent with the gurgling sound heard upon reduction. Indirect inguinal hernias follow the path of the inguinal canal, are related to a patent processus vaginalis, and are the most common type of hernia in children.
  • ➤ The statement "The sac contains omentum only" is incorrect when describing an indirect inguinal hernia in children, as these hernias may contain bowel, which is consistent with the gurgling sound heard upon reduction.
  • ➤ Indirect inguinal hernias follow the path of the inguinal canal, are related to a patent processus vaginalis, and are the most common type of hernia in children.

questions.text: The SPIKES protocol is a six-step process designed for what purpose?

options.label: C
options.text: Facilitating communication with a patient's family or attendants

questions.correct_answer: C. Facilitating communication with a patient's family or attendants
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Facilitating communication with a patient's family or attendants

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The SPIKES protocol is used to guide healthcare providers in delivering difficult or serious news to patients and their attendants, ensuring that the information is conveyed empathetically and effectively.
  • ➤ The SPIKES protocol is used to guide healthcare providers in delivering difficult or serious news to patients and their attendants, ensuring that the information is conveyed empathetically and effectively.

questions.text: A 34 years old male came with pain and watering in the right eye for 36 hours. On examination, a 3x2 cm corneal ulcer is seen with elevated margins, feathery hyphae, finger like projections and minimal hypopyon in cornea. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aspergillosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The feathery hyphae and finger-like projections of a corneal ulcer with minimal hypopyon are indicative of Aspergillosis, a fungal cause of keratitis, particularly in the setting of vegetative injury
  • ➤ The feathery hyphae and finger-like projections of a corneal ulcer with minimal hypopyon are indicative of Aspergillosis, a fungal cause of keratitis, particularly in the setting of vegetative injury

questions.text: Spontaneous healing of a genitourinary fistula via continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter is more likely to happen in which of the following settings?

options.label: A
options.text: The fistula is large, greater than 2 cm.

options.label: B
options.text: The fistula is small, 2 to 3 mm.

options.label: C
options.text: The fistula is related to pelvic radiation.

options.label: D
options.text: The catheter is left in place for a minimum of 8 weeks.

questions.correct_answer: B. The fistula is small, 2 to 3 mm.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Small genitourinary fistulas, particularly those measuring 2 to 3 mm, have a higher likelihood of spontaneous healing with conservative management, including continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter. The success of this approach diminishes with larger fistulas, those caused by radiation damage, and is not solely dependent on the duration of catheterization.
  • ➤ Small genitourinary fistulas, particularly those measuring 2 to 3 mm, have a higher likelihood of spontaneous healing with conservative management, including continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter.
  • ➤ The success of this approach diminishes with larger fistulas, those caused by radiation damage, and is not solely dependent on the duration of catheterization.

questions.text: In the aftermath of a bus accident, several casualties present at the emergency department. As the attending physician following ATLS guidelines, which patient should be prioritized for immediate intervention?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient with a severe head injury

questions.correct_answer: B. The patient with airway compromise
questions.explanation: Ans. B) The patient with airway compromise

questions.text: In a recent analysis aimed at improving immune-based therapies, a team of immunologists is categorizing cells based on their capacity to present antigens to T cells. This classification is crucial for understanding interactions that may influence therapeutic outcomes. Given this focus, which of the following cell types is not typically involved in the function of presenting antigens?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thymocytes are the T cells present in thymus; and T cells NEVER act as APC; infact APCs present the antigen to T cells.

questions.text: A 32-year Rh negative woman had a normal delivery after that the following test was done. What is this test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kleihauer Betke Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Kleihauer Betke test is performed on Rh-negative women after delivery to detect and quantify fetal red blood cells in the maternal circulation. This helps in determining the need for and appropriate dosage of Rh immunoglobulin to prevent Rh sensitization, which could have implications for future pregnancies.
  • ➤ The Kleihauer Betke test is performed on Rh-negative women after delivery to detect and quantify fetal red blood cells in the maternal circulation.
  • ➤ This helps in determining the need for and appropriate dosage of Rh immunoglobulin to prevent Rh sensitization, which could have implications for future pregnancies.

questions.text: What is the initial investigation of choice for evaluating a child with suspected strabismus?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Cover Uncover Test is the primary investigation for a child with suspected strabismus to identify if a manifest or latent strabismus is present and determine the angle of deviation.

questions.text: In a research study focusing on the structural analysis of antibodies, a team is using papain to understand the functional components of immunoglobulins. Papain, a proteolytic enzyme, is utilized to dissect antibodies into their respective parts. Based on this application, what are the expected products when papain digests an immunoglobulin molecule?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papain cleaves Ig below hinge region: produces 2 Fab + 1 Fc fragments Pepsin cleaves Ig above hinge region: produces one F(ab’2) fragment + many smaller fragments
  • ➤ Papain cleaves Ig below hinge region: produces 2 Fab + 1 Fc fragments
  • ➤ Pepsin cleaves Ig above hinge region: produces one F(ab’2) fragment + many smaller fragments

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy presents with growth retardation and delayed developmental milestones. His hair is sparse, kinky, and breaks easily. He has a history of seizures and has been notably hypotonic since birth. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Menkes disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The clinical features of Menkes disease are given in the question stem, which is a X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, leading to impaired copper transport and utilization.
  • ➤ The clinical features of Menkes disease are given in the question stem, which is a X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, leading to impaired copper transport and utilization.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male, who received a kidney transplant 2 years ago and has been on chronic immunosuppressive therapy, presents with multiple hyperkeratotic lesions on sun-exposed areas of the skin. Biopsy of one lesion confirms malignancy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin

questions.correct_answer: B. Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Squamous cell carcinoma of skin

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman gives a history of sharp pain in the lower abdomen for 2–3 days every month approximately 2 weeks before the menses. The most probable etiology for her pain is:
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mittelschmerz is a benign condition characterized by unilateral, mid-cycle abdominal pain corresponding with ovulation, approximately 2 weeks prior to menstruation.
  • ➤ Mittelschmerz is a benign condition characterized by unilateral, mid-cycle abdominal pain corresponding with ovulation, approximately 2 weeks prior to menstruation.

questions.text: A 2-month-old child with fever, irritability, dry oral mucosa, sunken eyes, and skin pustules is evaluated at a subcenter. The child weighs 2 kg and exhibits signs of dehydration and potential serious infection. Which initial action is most appropriate for the management of this child?

options.label: A
options.text: Refer to higher center with mother giving frequent sips of ORS

options.label: B
options.text: Immediately admit the child, give I/V fluids and then refer to higher center

options.label: C
options.text: Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center in an ambulance with sips of ORS along the way ​​​

options.label: D
options.text: Send child home with few packets of ORS and call after 3 days

questions.correct_answer: C. Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center in an ambulance with sips of ORS along the way ​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Give first dose of antibiotic and refer to higher center in an ambulance with sips of ORS along the way

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In young infants showing signs of possible serious bacterial infection and dehydration, the initial management should include administration of the first dose of antibiotics and urgent referral to a higher center with supportive hydration measures during transport.

questions.text: A patient undergoes photodynamic therapy (PDT) for a neovascular retinal lesion. Following the procedure, the ophthalmologist observes changes in the color of the lesion. What is the immediate post-procedural colour change of the lesion typically seen after photodynamic therapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The immediate post-procedural color change of a lesion after photodynamic therapy is that it typically appears white, reflecting the photodynamic effects on neovascular and surrounding tissue within the retina.
  • ➤ The immediate post-procedural color change of a lesion after photodynamic therapy is that it typically appears white, reflecting the photodynamic effects on neovascular and surrounding tissue within the retina.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with colicky abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. She reports weight loss following a keto-diet in the past few months. On investigation, the small bowel appears normal, but a CECT of the abdomen reveals compression of the D3 segment of the duodenum due to narrowing of the angle of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). Which of the following is the best option for treatment of this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Administration of medications to relieve pain

options.label: C
options.text: Feeding the patient to promote weight gain

options.label: D
options.text: Endoscopic intervention to widen the narrowed angle

questions.correct_answer: C. Feeding the patient to promote weight gain
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Feeding the patient to promote weight gain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial treatment for SMA Syndrome is conservative, focusing on nutritional support to promote weight gain and increase the mesenteric fat pad, thereby relieving the compression of the duodenum.
  • ➤ The initial treatment for SMA Syndrome is conservative, focusing on nutritional support to promote weight gain and increase the mesenteric fat pad, thereby relieving the compression of the duodenum.

questions.text: During rounds in the hospital's infectious disease unit, a medical team reviews a case of a patient treated with ceftriaxone and amikacin. Recent culture results indicate that an ESBL (Extended Spectrum Beta-Lactamase) producing Klebsiella species has been identified. Given the resistance profile of ESBL-producing organisms, which of the following adjustments to the patient's antibiotic regimen would be most appropriate?

options.label: A
options.text: Continue with the same antibiotic but in a higher dose

options.label: C
options.text: Start imipenem in place of ceftriaxone

questions.correct_answer: C. Start imipenem in place of ceftriaxone
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ESBL (Extended spectrum beta lactamases) are resistant to all Penicillin and 1st/2nd/3rd cephalosporin and monobactam; which can be overcome by addition of β lactamase inhibitor
  • ➤ ESBL (Extended spectrum beta lactamases) are resistant to all Penicillin and 1st/2nd/3rd cephalosporin and monobactam; which can be overcome by addition of β lactamase inhibitor
  • ➤ like clavulanic acid other alternate which can be given are:
  • ➤ Carbapenems like Imipenem and meropenem Cephamycins (like cefoxitin and cefotetan ) Different class of antibiotics like aminoglycoside
  • ➤ Carbapenems like Imipenem and meropenem
  • ➤ Cephamycins (like cefoxitin and cefotetan )
  • ➤ Different class of antibiotics like aminoglycoside

questions.text: A 35-year-old male who recently had a laparoscopic cholecystectomy presents on postoperative day 3 with fever. An ultrasonographic evaluation reveals a 5x5 cm fluid collection in the right subdiaphragmatic space. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Re-explore the wound with T-tube insertion

questions.explanation: Ans. C) Pigtail insertion and drainage

questions.text: A female presents to OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea complaints of bleeding per vagina and mild abdominal pain. The urine pregnancy test is positive and hCG level is 2800 IU/L. On investigation, mass is seen on the left adnexa measuring 3 x 2 cm. She is hemodynamically stable. How will you manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a hemodynamically stable patient with a suspected ectopic pregnancy, a single-dose methotrexate injection is an appropriate initial management strategy, especially when the ectopic mass is small (less than 3-4 cm) and hCG levels are low (less than 5000 IU/L). This approach can effectively resolve the ectopic pregnancy without the need for surgical intervention, preserving the patient's reproductive potential.
  • ➤ In a hemodynamically stable patient with a suspected ectopic pregnancy, a single-dose methotrexate injection is an appropriate initial management strategy, especially when the ectopic mass is small (less than 3-4 cm) and hCG levels are low (less than 5000 IU/L).
  • ➤ This approach can effectively resolve the ectopic pregnancy without the need for surgical intervention, preserving the patient's reproductive potential.

questions.text: Which of the following polymerases are known to have proofreading abilities that ensure high fidelity during PCR?

options.label: C
options.text: Both Pfu Polymerase and Taq Polymerase

questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pfu DNA polymerase, derived from Pyrococcus furiosus, has superior thermostability and proofreading properties compared to other thermostable polymerase such as Taq polymerase.
  • ➤ Pfu DNA polymerase, derived from Pyrococcus furiosus, has superior thermostability and proofreading properties compared to other thermostable polymerase such as Taq polymerase.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomy of the kidney?

options.label: A
options.text: Right renal artery is longer than left renal artery

options.label: B
options.text: Right renal vein is longer than left renal vein

options.label: C
options.text: Left renal artery is longer than right renal artery

options.label: D
options.text: The anterior most structure at renal hilum is the renal artery

questions.correct_answer: A. Right renal artery is longer than left renal artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Right renal artery is longer than left renal artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The right renal artery is longer than the left renal artery due to the relative positions of the aorta and the inferior vena cava, which necessitates a longer course for the right renal artery to reach the right kidney.
  • ➤ The right renal artery is longer than the left renal artery due to the relative positions of the aorta and the inferior vena cava, which necessitates a longer course for the right renal artery to reach the right kidney.

questions.text: Chocolate agar, a variant of blood agar where blood cells have been lysed by heating, is used primarily to isolate fastidious organisms. Which of the following organisms can grow on chocolate agar? Neisseria meningitidis Haemophilus influenzae Vibrio cholerae Listeria monocytogenes Staphylococcus aureus
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chocolate agar (an Enriched media): It is the heated blood agar, blood is added to the molten nutrient agar at 70°C . It is more nutritious than blood agar
  • ➤ Chocolate agar (an Enriched media): It is the heated blood agar, blood is added to the molten nutrient agar at 70°C . It is more nutritious than blood agar
  • ➤ Chocolate agar
  • ➤ 70°C

questions.text: A 25-year primi with preeclampsia and fetal distress underwent an emergency LSCS (Lower segment caesarean surgery). Following delivery of the baby, this was the appearance of the uterus. What could have been the reason for fetal distress?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Abruptio Placenta

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of preeclampsia and fetal distress necessitating an emergency cesarean section, abruptio placenta is a plausible cause of fetal distress, particularly if there are abnormal findings in the uterus after delivery. This condition involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, leading to decreased placental function and fetal distress.
  • ➤ In the context of preeclampsia and fetal distress necessitating an emergency cesarean section, abruptio placenta is a plausible cause of fetal distress, particularly if there are abnormal findings in the uterus after delivery.
  • ➤ This condition involves the premature separation of the placenta from the uterus, leading to decreased placental function and fetal distress.

questions.text: Identifying organisms that can resist moist environments is crucial for maintaining sterile conditions. Which bacterium is known for its ability to often contaminate disinfectant solutions?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudomonas is resistant to no. of disinfectant solutions such as savlon or Dettol.
  • ➤ Pseudomonas is resistant to no. of disinfectant solutions such as savlon or Dettol.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea has the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis? Normal stature Thelarche – absent FSH, LH – high Karyotype - 46 XX
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gonadal dysgenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of primary amenorrhea, lack of breast development, high FSH and LH levels, and a normal 46 XX karyotype suggest gonadal dysgenesis, a condition where the gonads are non-functional despite the individual having a typical female chromosomal makeup. This leads to primary amenorrhea and lack of development of secondary sexual characteristics due to insufficient sex steroid production.
  • ➤ The presence of primary amenorrhea, lack of breast development, high FSH and LH levels, and a normal 46 XX karyotype suggest gonadal dysgenesis, a condition where the gonads are non-functional despite the individual having a typical female chromosomal makeup.
  • ➤ This leads to primary amenorrhea and lack of development of secondary sexual characteristics due to insufficient sex steroid production.

questions.text: During a laboratory training session, a group of postgraduate students is instructed on the operation and maintenance of an electron microscope. The instructor emphasizes the critical factors that can influence the performance and resolution of the microscope. Which of the following is a key factor affecting the functioning of an electron microscope?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In order to get visualized by EM, the specimen should be very thin (20 to 100 nm thickness).
  • ➤ In order to get visualized by EM, the specimen should be very thin (20 to 100 nm thickness).

questions.text: The following are related to bromocriptine therapy except:

options.label: A
options.text: It is used to inhibit inappropriate lactation with secondary amenorrhoea ​​​​​​

options.label: B
options.text: It is specific in suppressing only the prolactin secretion

options.label: C
options.text: If pregnancy occurs, there is increased incidence of multiple pregnancy ​​​​​

options.label: D
options.text: Its teratogenic effect on the fetus is inconclusive

questions.correct_answer: C. If pregnancy occurs, there is increased incidence of multiple pregnancy ​​​​​
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Bromocriptine therapy is not associated with an increased incidence of multiple pregnancies. Its primary use in reproductive medicine is to treat conditions related to hyperprolactinemia, such as inappropriate lactation and amenorrhea, by suppressing prolactin secretion.
  • ➤ Bromocriptine therapy is not associated with an increased incidence of multiple pregnancies.
  • ➤ Its primary use in reproductive medicine is to treat conditions related to hyperprolactinemia, such as inappropriate lactation and amenorrhea, by suppressing prolactin secretion.

questions.text: Identify the type of covering used for burns wound:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thiersch graft

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The Thiersch graft, a split-thickness skin graft, involves the transplantation of epidermis and part of the dermis from a donor site to a wound, commonly used for large burn injuries due to its ability to cover extensive areas and facilitate wound healing.
  • ➤ The Thiersch graft, a split-thickness skin graft, involves the transplantation of epidermis and part of the dermis from a donor site to a wound, commonly used for large burn injuries due to its ability to cover extensive areas and facilitate wound healing.

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida is admitted at 39 weeks gestation with painless antepartum hemorrhage. On examination uterus is soft non-tender and head engaged. The management for her would be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trans vaginal ultrasound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of a primigravida at term with painless antepartum hemorrhage, a careful pelvic examination in the operating theatre is recommended to assess the situation while being prepared for potential immediate surgical intervention, considering the high suspicion for placenta previa or another placental issue. This approach allows for rapid response to the findings and minimizes the risk to both mother and baby.
  • ➤ In the management of a primigravida at term with painless antepartum hemorrhage, a careful pelvic examination in the operating theatre is recommended to assess the situation while being prepared for potential immediate surgical intervention, considering the high suspicion for placenta previa or another placental issue.
  • ➤ This approach allows for rapid response to the findings and minimizes the risk to both mother and baby.

questions.text: Which of the following is an antagonist of a peptide and is used to reduce chemotherapy induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aprepitant is used as an NK1 receptor antagonist to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting by blocking the action of substance P at neurokinin-1 receptors in the brain's vomiting center. This makes it an effective part of the regimen for managing nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy, particularly in patients receiving highly emetogenic treatments.
  • ➤ Aprepitant is used as an NK1 receptor antagonist to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting by blocking the action of substance P at neurokinin-1 receptors in the brain's vomiting center.
  • ➤ This makes it an effective part of the regimen for managing nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy, particularly in patients receiving highly emetogenic treatments.

questions.text: During a training session for emergency responders, a discussion focuses on the categorization of bioterrorism agents according to their threat level and potential for public health impact. Which organisms are included in Category ‘A’ for bioterrorism threats, indicating the highest priority organisms that pose a risk to national security? Vibrio cholera Clostridium botulinum Yersinia pestis Bacillus anthracis Burkholderia mallei
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Category A Bioterrorism agents (WHO) include Botulism, Tularaemia, Anthrax, Smallpox, Plague, Viral hemorrhagic fevers (Filoviruses – Ebola & Marburg; Arenaviruses – Lassa, Machupo)
  • ➤ Category A Bioterrorism agents (WHO) include Botulism, Tularaemia, Anthrax, Smallpox, Plague, Viral hemorrhagic fevers (Filoviruses – Ebola & Marburg; Arenaviruses – Lassa, Machupo)

questions.text: An alcoholic developed intractable vomiting for 2 days with loose motions. Since he had decreased food intake and altered sensorium, he was brought to the hospital, where the fluid loss and dyselectrolytemia was aggressively corrected with fluid infusion. Post treatment, the patient started having quadriplegia and mutism. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The rapid correction of hyponatremia, particularly in individuals who are malnourished or chronically ill (such as those with chronic alcoholism), can lead to osmotic demyelination syndrome. This is characterized by neurological symptoms that can develop days after the overly rapid correction of sodium levels. Care must be taken to correct sodium slowly in at-risk patients to prevent this serious complication.
  • ➤ The rapid correction of hyponatremia, particularly in individuals who are malnourished or chronically ill (such as those with chronic alcoholism), can lead to osmotic demyelination syndrome.
  • ➤ This is characterized by neurological symptoms that can develop days after the overly rapid correction of sodium levels.
  • ➤ Care must be taken to correct sodium slowly in at-risk patients to prevent this serious complication.
